result.markdown:
--- title: "Activity 06" author: Robert Reiss date: 9-20-24 --- ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(leaflet) library(tidyverse) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── ✔ dplyr 1.1.4 ✔ readr 2.1.5 ✔ forcats 1.0.0 ✔ stringr 1.5.1 ✔ ggplot2 3.5.1 ✔ tibble 3.2.1 ✔ lubridate 1.9.3 ✔ tidyr 1.3.1 ✔ purrr 1.0.2 ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() ℹ Use the conflicted package () to force all conflicts to become errors ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) ``` ::: # Exercise 1 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} fave_places <- read.csv("https://ajohns24.github.io/data/112/our_fave_places.csv") # Check it out head(fave_places) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` latitude longitude 1 46 -123 2 33 52 3 48 -90 4 36 -112 5 59 25 6 39 -106 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load the leaflet package library(leaflet) # Just a plotting frame leaflet(data = fave_places) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Now what do we have? leaflet(data = fave_places) %>% addTiles() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Now what do we have? # longitude and latitude refer to the variables in our data leaflet(data = fave_places) %>% addTiles() %>% addMarkers(lng = ~longitude, lat = ~latitude) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Since we named them "longitude" and "latitude", the function # automatically recognizes these variables. No need to write them! leaflet(data = fave_places) %>% addTiles() %>% addMarkers() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: # Exercise 2 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load package needed to change color library(gplots) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Attaching package: 'gplots' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` The following object is masked from 'package:stats': lowess ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # We can add colored circles instead of markers at each location leaflet(data = fave_places) %>% addTiles() %>% addCircles(color = col2hex("red")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # We can change the background # Mark locations with yellow dots # And connect the dots, in their order in the dataset, with green lines # (These green lines don't mean anything here, but would if this were somebody's travel path!) leaflet(data = fave_places) %>% addProviderTiles("USGS") %>% addCircles(weight = 10, opacity = 1, color = col2hex("yellow")) %>% addPolylines( lng = ~longitude, lat = ~latitude, color = col2hex("green") ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: # Exercise 3 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Import starbucks location data starbucks <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/starbucks.csv") # Don't worry about the syntax starbucks_mn <- starbucks %>% filter(Country == "US", State.Province == "MN") # Leaflet map of sbucks in MN leaflet(data = starbucks_mn) %>% addTiles() %>% addMarkers() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Assuming "Longitude" and "Latitude" are longitude and latitude, respectively ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(starbucks, aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.2, size = 0.2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](activity_06_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Exercise 4a ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load the package library(rnaturalearth) # Get info about country boundaries across the world # in a "sf" or simple feature format world_boundaries <- ne_countries(returnclass = "sf") ``` ::: # Exercise 4b ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # What does this code produce? # What geom are we using for the point map? ggplot(world_boundaries) + geom_sf() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](activity_06_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load package needed to change map theme library(mosaic) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Registered S3 method overwritten by 'mosaic': method from fortify.SpatialPolygonsDataFrame ggplot2 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` The 'mosaic' package masks several functions from core packages in order to add additional features. The original behavior of these functions should not be affected by this. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Attaching package: 'mosaic' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` The following object is masked from 'package:Matrix': mean ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` The following objects are masked from 'package:dplyr': count, do, tally ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` The following object is masked from 'package:purrr': cross ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` The following object is masked from 'package:ggplot2': stat ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': binom.test, cor, cor.test, cov, fivenum, IQR, median, prop.test, quantile, sd, t.test, var ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` The following objects are masked from 'package:base': max, mean, min, prod, range, sample, sum ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Add a point for each Starbucks # NOTE: The Starbucks info is in our starbucks data, not world_boundaries # How does this change how we use geom_point?! ggplot(world_boundaries) + geom_sf() + geom_point( data = starbucks, aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude), alpha = 0.3, size = 0.2, color = "darkgreen" ) + theme_map() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](activity_06_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Exercise 4c # Exercise 5 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # We'll learn this syntax soon! Don't worry about it now. starbucks_cma <- starbucks %>% filter(Country %in% c('CA', 'MX', 'US')) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cma_boundaries <- ne_states( country = c("canada", "mexico", "united states of america"), returnclass = "sf") ``` :::
